BC-SCIENCE-TIMES-BUDGET-1STLD-WRITETHRUNYT 
  
 (Eds, add SCI-GALAXY-CANNIBALISM)  

   The New York Times News Service plans the following    Science
Times    stories for papers of Tuesday, April 11:

   SCI-ASTEROIDS (Undated) _ Taking cautious, baby steps, a
spacecraft called NEAR Shoemaker is to settle Monday into a closer
orbit of an asteroid it has been circling for almost two months.
Guided by gentle shoves from small thruster rockets, the robotic
craft is taking up a circular orbit 62-miles from the center of
Eros for more detailed studies. After spending about 11 days at
this altitude, the craft is to take another downstep on its way to
settling in at a height of 31 miles for months of closeup
observations of the pitted, tumbling, rocky mass below. By Warren
E. Leary.

   With graphic.

   SCI-GALAXY-CANNIBALISM (Undated) _ Astronomers have long
suspected that a dark secret about Earth's galaxy, the Milky Way.
They have even seen other galaxies engaging in the macabre behavior
at the core of this secret. But without irrefutable proof,
astronomers refused to admit that it might be commonplace closer to
home. Now, sadly, they have that proof. The Milky Way is a chronic
cannibal. It consumes other galaxies and makes their stars its own.
(550 words)

   SCI-FRUIT-FLY (Undated) _ The Drosophila fruit fly, whose genome
was just decoded, has attained vast prominence in human affairs
because it is one of the principal model organisms studied by
biologists as a means of understanding the general design of life.
Because of the unity of evolution, the fly's genes and those of
people overlap considerably. Their advocates, who call themselves
fly people, are easily provoked into confessing that they think of
people as large flies that lack wings. And over the past 93 years,
the fly has a long and celebrated history in biology and genetics.
By Nichols Wade. (1400 words)

   SCI-HEPATITIS-C (Washington) _ The discovery of 50-year-old Army
blood samples in helping scientists determine what the best course
of treatment may be for hepatitis C. Now, some contend that
aggressive treatment, which can be painful and cause side effects,
should be used in almost all cases. Other say that the odds of
contracting symptoms of the disease are small and the more moderate
approaches are called for. By Gina Kolata. (1950 words)

   With photo, NYT1.

   SCI-VA-ARCHEO (Philadelphia) _ With new evidence, archaeologists
have more firmly dated a site in Virginia at 15,900 years, making
it much earlier than sites found on the West Coast and raising the
possibility that first human occupation sites were on East Coast.
It also gives further credence for placing human in the Western
Hemisphere earlier than previously thought. By John Noble Wilford.

   With map.

   SCI-BIG-ICEBERGS (Undated) _ Two mammoth icebergs have broken
off the Antarctic ice cap in the past several weeks, including one
that is the largest in more than four decades. By Henry Fountain.
(300 words)

   SCI-GORILLA-TECH (Undated) _ Since Dr. Dian Fossey began
studying the mountain gorillas of Rwanda and adjoining countries in
the 1960s, researchers have tracked, with some interruptions, the
fortunes of these engaging creatures in a perpetually endangered
jungle. Now, a collaboration of several American and Rwandan
institutions is taking that program to the edge of high technology,
using remote sensing from satellites and aircraft and electronic
trackers on the ground to create a vastly expanded, instantly
accessible record of the gorillas and their habitat in digital
form. By James Glanz. (1325 words)

   With photo, NYT2, and a map.

   SCI-VAROS (Washington) _ Remedios Varo, considered one of the
greatest surrealist painters of the 20th century, is at last
beginning to receive international acclaim, including the
admiration of a cadre not always known for its art house savvy: the
scientific community. In a recent symposium, an expert described
how the artist metaphorically conveyed some of the most
revolutionary and complex scientific theories of the age, from
Einstein's special theory of relativity and Darwin's theory of
evolution by natural selection to the premise that humans are the
stuff of stars. By Natalie Angier (1250 words)

   With photos, NYT3,4.

   SCI-WATCH (Undated) _ News and notes on science: Items on the
tail of Comet Hyakutake (it's 330 million miles long), e. coli
contamination in cow manure and ways to kill it, and the thornback
ray's method of purging its stomach. By Henry Fountain. (700 words)

   SCI-HEART-DIET (Undated) _ Medicare is now undertaking a radical
diet experiment in several centers to determine if critically ill
heart patients can become better by radically altering their diets
and their daily routines under the Dean Ornisch diet. They hope to
determine if they can cut costs for heart procedures through
preventive steps. They also should reveal on a large scale just how
effective the diet, which has its critics, really is. By Barbara
Whitaker. (1725 words)

   SCI-BROCKOVITCH-SCIENCE (Undated) _ Reflections column. Many
scientists are offended by the movie ``Erin Brockovitch.'' The
problem, they say, is not that they cannot enjoy a good yarn in
which virtue triumphs over evil and the little guys win. It is a
more subtle: while it is easy to see that the sex and even the
violence in movies are fantasies, it is hard for any but scientists
to discern when science in movies crosses the line from verity to
hyperbole and indoctrination. The end result, some say, is to help
perpetuate misconceptions about scientific evidence and about the
risks of everyday life. By Gina Kolata. (900 words)

   SCI-BRODY-HEALTH (Undated) _ The Personal Health column: With
the arrival of spring, allergies are not necessarily inevitable.
Many drugs, old and new, are on the market now and have proved to
be highly effective. Some are grossly underused. By Jane E. Brody.
(1250 words)

   SCI-CHILDREN-ALONE (Undated) _ Twelve to 14 percent of American
children ages 5 to 12 spend some time home alone after school, a
new study has found, but the period without adult supervision
averages only an hour, most of the children are older, and many
seem to welcome a measure of privacy and independence. The study
also outlines just what the children do when the parents are not
home. By Leslie Berger. (850 words)

   SCI-VITAL-SIGNS (Undated) _ News and notes on health and
fitness:

   _ Scientists researching the sweet tooth in mice have recognized
a gene that may keep them thin regardless of eating habits. They
hope they can eventually use the knowledge for people. (240 words)

   _ Millions of Americans are living with pain, and are resigned
to that condition, a new study says. The Arthritis Foundation
reported last week that a Gallup poll of about 2,000 people found
that regular pain was a pervasive part of American life, but that
few people seek medical attention for it. (190 words)

   _ Smoking in pregnancy has long been linked to general problems
like premature deliveries and babies with low birth weights, but a
new study reports that it may also be responsible for two specific
birth defects: cleft palate and cleft lip. (280 words)

   _ Scientists have found a way to determine if people are in
early stages of Alzheimer's by comparing MRI brain scans. (300
words)

   _ Researchers are using magnets to help move cancer-fighting
drugs laced with metallic substances to tumors. (165 words)

   SCI-Q&A (Undated) _ A science question answered: What is the
rationale behind daylight saving time? You can't really ``save''
daylight. By C. Claiborne Ray. (300 words)

   Photos, where indicated, are being sent to NYT photo clients.
Graphics, to NYT graphic clients. Non-subscribers can make
